revised_title: Hourly Observations of Magnetic Declination in the Arctic Sea
tldr: This article discusses the hourly observations of magnetic declination made by Sir Francis Leopold M'Clintock and his team during their Arctic expedition in 1858-59. The observations were compared with those made by Captain Maguire in 1852, 1853, and 1854. The results showed that the intensity of the disturbing force was less at Port Kennedy than at Point Barrow, and the disturbances formed distinct categories of easterly and westerly deflections. The author also reviewed the phenomena of the solar-diurnal variation and the caution needed when deriving the epochs of the decennial period from the magnitude of the diurnal range of the declination-magnet.
